Results.Title: Mixed Reality - Terminology, Techniques, and UX Challenges of the HoloLens
Results.Abstract:
Do you want to explore Mars? Model a building on your conference room table? Play Minecraft in your living room? All of these things are being done today using Mixed Reality. Mixed Reality provides an immersive UXD experience that is unrivaled.

This talk will use the HoloLens and Unity 3D to give a crash course in AR/MR concepts, how an MR application is put together and some of the UX and design considerations. This includes:

• Real World Understanding (Spatial Mapping, Spatial Understanding)
• Holograms (Billboarding, Placement, Physics)
• Control (Gaze, Cursor, Gestures, Speech)

You’ll leave with an understanding of HoloLens terminology and techniques, by watching a real HoloLens app get built step-by-step using each of these AR concepts.
Results.Author: Cameron Vetter
Results.AuthorBio: Software Development is my passion. I have over 15 years of experience using Microsoft tools to develop software. Currently I am a Senior Software Architect at Safenet Consulting, where I get to do what I love... Architect, Design, and Develop great software! I currently focus on Microservices, SOA, Azure, IOT, Xamarin, and HoloLens.

Results.Title: Providing Code to the Codeless
Results.Abstract: PowerApps, Flows, and the Common Data Service are some new codeless tools Office 365 provides to create mobile applications, automate processes, and integrate systems. The challenge with using pre-built components is that in most cases it will never quite be a complete solution when trying to solve a more complex business problem. Luckily, as developers, we can fall back to writing code to fill in some gaps or provide more advanced functionality. In this session you'll get an overview of how these different applications work, why you might want to use them, and how you can extend them.
Results.Author: Jason Lattimer
Results.AuthorBio: Jason Lattimer (Greenville, WI) is a Development Manager with PowerObjects (Minneapolis, MN) and a Microsoft Business Solutions MVP. Other interests outside of creating custom solutions for Dynamics CRM/365 include Azure and developer tools. When not helping out in forums or talking to user groups he's busy writing code and tools to hopefully make other developer's lives easier.

Results.Title: NoSQL: an introduction via logging with Serilog and the ELK-stack
Results.Abstract: Many of us are familiar with traditional relational databases, and NoSQL databases are new and unfamiliar territory.  NoSQL databases deserve our attention because they provide  a good way to store more unstructured or heterogeneous data -- and logging is a good example of just such heterogeneous data.  In this session we will review a definition of NoSQL and some of the platform options.  Following that, we will use the .NET Serilog package to write log entries to Elasticsearch (hosted in a Docker container) and review, visualize, and search those log entries using Kibana.
Results.Author: Erik Dahl
Results.AuthorBio:
I've been working in technology - both development and management - for more than 20 years.  Lately have been heavily involved with API development and security, authentication and authorization within IdentityServer3, and front-end work with ASP.NET, Bootstrap, Kendo, and TypeScript.  Passionate about finding ways to enable developers to focus on application code rather than plumbing code.

Currently a Principal Architect at RealPage, Inc.

Results.Title: All Request are Asynchronous
Results.Abstract:
When should you use a service bus vs. a web service call? When should you use REST vs. SOAP? Should you use CQRS? Should you build Microservices?

Take a look under the hood of your network stack. What promises does it make? What promises can it actually keep?

We have many architectural choices to make within a distributed system. Those decisions depend upon the nature of the messaging infrastructure upon which we build. Different options are good for different parts of the system. But some of the advice that you may have heard is wrong. Learn what's really happening inside of the components you choose. And use that knowledge to build more reliable distributed systems.
Results.Author: Michael L Perry
Results.AuthorBio:
Software is math. Every class is a theorem. The compiler is the proof. And unit tests check our work.

Michael has recorded Pluralsight courses on CQRS, XAML Patterns, and Cryptography, in addition to Provable Code. He maintains the spoon-bending Assisticant, Correspondence, and Jinaga open-source libraries. He podcasts about the intersection between software and mathematics at qedcode.com. And he helps his clients at Improving benefit from the power of software mathematics.

Results.Title: How Not to Destroy Data
Results.Abstract:
CRUD apps destroy data.

Delete is an obviously destructive operation, but Update is no better. Updates overwrite the data that was once present. What would software look like if the only valid operations were Create and Read?

Historical Modeling is a technique for designing and building software systems that permit only inserts, no updates, no deletes. The only way to "modify" an object is to insert related records. You can then read the state of the object by querying for the presence or absence of those related records. We'll start with the assumption that all records are immutable and indelible. From there, we'll build a set of patterns that yield some surprising benefits.

With a historical model, synchronizing disparate nodes is trivial: just insert what you don't yet have. Building offline-first web applications is easy. Viewing a snapshot of the system at any point in the past is a simple query.

Let's build a historical model together, and see these benefits for ourselves. Let's put aside the assumptions of CRUD applications and discover a whole new set of patterns. Once you master these techniques, you will never destroy data again.
Results.Author: Michael L Perry
Results.AuthorBio:
Software is math. Every class is a theorem. The compiler is the proof. And unit tests check our work.

Michael has recorded Pluralsight courses on CQRS, XAML Patterns, and Cryptography, in addition to Provable Code. He maintains the spoon-bending Assisticant, Correspondence, and Jinaga open-source libraries. He podcasts about the intersection between software and mathematics at qedcode.com. And he helps his clients at Improving benefit from the power of software mathematics.

Results.Title: The Introvert’s Agile Survival Guide
Results.Abstract:
According to best-selling author Susan Cain, introverts are often discriminated against in our extrovert-dominated society.  Although approximately two thirds of people in the United States are considered extroverts, the majority of IT professionals are introverts.  Many Agile practices, however, tend to favor the extrovert, leaving introverts with a frequent feeling of being yanked outside their comfort zone.  

Attending meetings, working in an open team room, and interacting with team members throughout the day can leave the introvert feeling exhausted and yearning for a quiet environment to think and be productive.  The introvert may feel it’s necessary to become an extrovert to survive Agile, but not only is this unrealistic – it’s unnecessary.  Introverts and extroverts are all welcome at this session.  We’ll cover strategies for introverts to increase their job satisfaction by expanding their comfort zone and how extroverts can increase empathy for the plight of their introverted team members.
Results.Author: Ken Howard
Results.AuthorBio: Ken is President of Improving Houston, and has been involved in most aspects of software development, training and mentoring for over 30 years. Ken’s specialty is helping companies increase productivity through efficient practices and pragmatic organizational dynamics, which was the topic of the Addison-Wesley book that he co-authored titled Individuals and Interactions: An Agile Guide.

Results.Title: The Agile Business Analyst
Results.Abstract:
Business Analysts can play a key role on project teams, but when adopting agile software development it’s often unclear how to best use the skills of a Business Analyst (BA).     

This session will provide a description of key skills and tools that skillful BA’s often use.   These will be aligned with the approach used in typical agile software development methods such as Scrum and Kanban, and best practices for maximizing the value of your BA will be offered.
Results.Author: Ken Howard
Results.AuthorBio: Ken is President of Improving Houston, and has been involved in most aspects of software development, training and mentoring for over 30 years. Ken’s specialty is helping companies increase productivity through efficient practices and pragmatic organizational dynamics, which was the topic of the Addison-Wesley book that he co-authored titled Individuals and Interactions: An Agile Guide.

Results.Title: The Future of Agile
Results.Abstract:
Thirteen years after the Agile Manifesto, how are we doing? Is it what the manifesto authors expected? Has our industry improved as a whole?  Is agile just a passing fad that will fade away? We will take a brief journey back through the history of project management, technology, and organizational behavior.    

The evolutionary patterns of changes to each of these help us see how we got to where we are today, while providing useful forecasting insight. You might be surprised to learn the true origins of agile as we learn about emerging trends that give a glimpse into the future of product development.
Results.Author: Ken Howard
Results.AuthorBio: Ken is President of Improving Houston, and has been involved in most aspects of software development, training and mentoring for over 30 years. Ken’s specialty is helping companies increase productivity through efficient practices and pragmatic organizational dynamics, which was the topic of the Addison-Wesley book that he co-authored titled Individuals and Interactions: An Agile Guide.

Results.Title: Which Azure Storage Option Should I Choose?
Results.Abstract: Deciding which Azure storage product to use is a difficult and important decision. There are many options, and chances are you haven’t used most of them. Knowing the performance tradeoffs, scalability and costs among the many storage options available is essential for planning any cloud-based architecture. Traditionally, relational storage like SQL Server has been the default choice, but with so many new cloud-based products that are affordable and easy to use, it’s time to start considering other options. When is NoSql the best choice? Should I use Azure Storage tables or DocumentDb? When does it make sense to use an Elastic Database Pool? What about Redis Cache? Before jumping in, learn what purpose each option serves best so you can leverage Azure effectively.
Results.Author: Anne Bougie
Results.AuthorBio: Anne Bougie is a Senior Software Developer at Concurrency, Inc. Anne has been in software development since the mid-90s in many different roles including developer, architect, business analyst, tester, project manager and teacher. She has expertise in a variety of languages and platforms and enjoys speaking as an opportunity to break down complex technical topics to help other understand them. She has been developing for the cloud since 2009. When she is not coding, she is either maintaining her beehives or playing with Arduino projects for beekeeping.

Results.Title: Video Streaming with Azure Media Services
Results.Abstract: Recently, the introduction of small, easy to use drone cameras and action cameras have encouraged amateur videographers everywhere. How can we incorporate professional media tools to help our users share video content in our apps? From adaptive bitrate encoding, facial recognition, easy subtitling to video editing features, whether you need to stream to a small audience or thousands of concurrent users, Azure Media Services has many features that make it easy for developers. We’ll cover the features and the code to help you utilize what Azure has to offer.
Results.Author: Anne Bougie
Results.AuthorBio: Anne Bougie is a Senior Software Developer at Concurrency, Inc. Anne has been in software development since the mid-90s in many different roles including developer, architect, business analyst, tester, project manager and teacher. She has expertise in a variety of languages and platforms and enjoys speaking as an opportunity to break down complex technical topics to help other understand them. She has been developing for the cloud since 2009. When she is not coding, she is either maintaining her beehives or playing with Arduino projects for beekeeping.

Results.Title: Level Up From Hardware Noob to Hardware Node
Results.Abstract: Go one step beyond the browser and leverage your existing JavaScript skills to explore the possibilities of hardware. Do you have an Arduino gathering dust, just waiting for an application beyond the hello world of blinking an LED? It’s time to take that hardware off the shelf, and learn how to create interactive experiences in the physical world. This session will explore how to utilize the popular Node robotics frameworks to control an Arduino, showing you how to get quickly up and running in this new and emerging world of hardware. In this session, we will go over how to get started in building a NodeBot, and then we will demo an actual NodeBot project. This is an ideal introductory session for those curious on how to get started with some of the popular microcontrollers and microprocessors using JavaScript.
Results.Author: Gabrielle Crevecoeur
Results.AuthorBio: Gabrielle Crevecoeur is a technical evangelist at Microsoft specializing in open source development. Her current focus is Node.js. Gabrielle is a recent graduate of Florida State University, where she majored in computer science. She is now attending the University of Illinois at Chicago, were she is working to her Masters of Science in Electrical Engineering. When Gabrielle is not programming, you can find her playing video games or watching Netflix.

Results.Title: Liven Up With Logic Apps
Results.Abstract: Complicated workflows getting you down? Well get ready to liven things up with Logic Apps. Create your workflows by doing LESS work and partaking in more "fun".Logic Apps provide a great way to simplify and implement scalable integrations and workflows in the cloud. Using a visual designer, Logic Apps allow you to implement workflows, connect with APIs and access several cloud tools at the click of a button (or two..). In this session, we will go over how to build Logic Apps, how to integrate APIs into your workflow, how Logic Apps can be a great way to handle data and how to connect your Logic App to an active Web Application (Node.js example will be used). This is an ideal introductory session for those curious on how to get started with Logic Apps and workflows and even those interested in learning about different methods of streaming data! It's time to kick back and relax as Logic Apps livens things up for you
Results.Author: Gabrielle Crevecoeur

She is now attending the University of Illinois at Chicago, were she is working to her Masters of Science in Electrical Engineering. When Gabrielle is not programming, you can find her playing video games or watching Netflix.

Results.Title: Swift Performance Tips for Busy iOS Developers
Results.Abstract:
Want to learn quick tips that will improve your apps performance and load time?  In this talk, we’ll explore the latest Swift techniques we can apply to create fast iOS apps. Topic discussed will include:
* The three dimensions of performance: allocation (stack vs heap), reference counting (less vs more), and method dispatch (static vs dynamic)
* Is Swift faster than Objective-C?
* Are structs faster than classes?
* Is inheritance faster than protocol extensions?
* Grand Central Dispatch patterns
* Whole module optimization
* Performance monitoring and more
Results.Author: Brad Broulik
Results.AuthorBio: Brad Broulik is an author, trainer, and principal developer specializing in iOS development at HealthPartners. He blogs at http://bradbroulik.blogspot.com.

Results.Title: A First View of Vue.js
Results.Abstract:
If you like the idea of React - with its focus on being small and performant as well as a virtual DOM that quickly renders modified components - but don't want to abandon the friendly atmosphere of Angular's MVVM, then you should check out Vue.js.

In this session, we will go over Vue.js, how it compares to other popular JavaScript frameworks and when you should consider using it.
Results.Author: Vince Bullinger
Results.AuthorBio: Vince has been a passionate developer and consultant since 2005. He is currently an independent contractor. He received his MCSD for .NET with C# back in 2008. In recent years, he’s immersed himself in front end technologies. Even more recently, he’s developed a passion for mobile development, specifically of the cross-platform variety. Outside of work, he's a husband and father and enjoys sports, games and learning everything about everything.

Results.Title: Any Platform, Any Build; Getting Started with Team Foundation Server Build
Results.Abstract: In this session you will learn how to create and manage build processes that automatically compile and test your applications.  These builds can be triggered manually or as part of an automated continuous integration process.  You can use the VSTS build system to build .NET, Xcode, Android, iOS, and other types of applications with code hosted in VSTS, GitHub, or other providers. Visual Studio Team Services simplifies continuous integration for your applications regardless of what platform you are targeting, or what language you are using.
Results.Author: Paul Hacker
Results.AuthorBio: Paul Hacker, a Solution Architect with AgileThought, has over 15 years of application architecture, design, development, and management expertise in Microsoft technologies. Paul has a depth of experience in ALM, Process Improvement, and Team Foundation Server.  Having distinguished himself as a leader in the IT industry he has been awarded the distinction of Microsoft MVP in the ALM category every year since 2006.

Results.Title: Release Management with Team Services
Results.Abstract: Learn the fundamentals of Release Management, how it relates to DevOps, and benefits it and continuous deployment bring to any organization.  More specifically, I will present an overview of Release Management. I will also cover what Visual Studio Team Services and Team Foundation Services are. We will look at the new Cross-Platform build system, discuss DevOps practices, and benefits of Release Management. Walk away with the knowledge you need to get started with Release Management Team Services.
Results.Author: Paul Hacker
Results.AuthorBio: Paul Hacker, a Solution Architect with AgileThought, has over 15 years of application architecture, design, development, and management expertise in Microsoft technologies. Paul has a depth of experience in ALM, Process Improvement, and Team Foundation Server.  Having distinguished himself as a leader in the IT industry he has been awarded the distinction of Microsoft MVP in the ALM category every year since 2006.

Results.Title: To the cloud Alice!!
Results.Abstract: Does it take you days to deploy your infrastructure? In this session we are going to introduce you to Azure Resource Manager and demonstrate how we create Azure Resource Manager (ARM) templates using Visual Studio 2017 and then deploy the infrastructure to Azure in minutes. We are going to peek under the covers of the ARM templates to show you what is going on inside the template and why you should be implementing it today. We will look at the Azure portal and walk through the infrastructure we deployed. Lastly we will look at the Azure Resource Template Visualizer and show you a great way to use it to get you started with ARM template creation.
Results.Author: Paul Hacker
Results.AuthorBio: 15 years of application architecture, design, development, and management expertise in Microsoft technologies. Paul has a depth of experience in ALM, Process Improvement, and Team Foundation Server.  Having distinguished himself as a leader in the IT industry he has been awarded the distinction of Microsoft MVP in the ALM category every year since 2006.

Results.Title: You got your Dev in my Ops, You got your Ops in my Dev
Results.Abstract: Want to improve the quality of your code and get it into customers’ hands faster, with fewer delays and a better view of the end-to-end deployment pipeline? Join this session to learn how IT and Developer practitioners can use Visual Studio Online to accelerate their DevOps journey, thanks to flexible, cross-platform capabilities and built-in tasks that integrate with and preserve existing investments.
Results.Author: Paul Hacker
Results.AuthorBio: Paul Hacker, a Solution Architect with AgileThought, has over 15 years of application architecture, design, development, and management expertise in Microsoft technologies. Paul has a depth of experience in ALM, Process Improvement, and Team Foundation Server.  Having distinguished himself as a leader in the IT industry he has been awarded the distinction of Microsoft MVP in the ALM category every year since 2006.

Results.Title: Let's Learn CSS Grid
Results.Abstract: CSS Grid Layout is gaining more browser support everyday! But what is it? How does it work? Why should you use it? And what are some practical ways you can incorporate it into your project? I'll show you how CSS Grid solves layout problems we've had for years, and how it's a great compliment to the other layout tools we have.
Results.Author: Timothy Smith
Results.AuthorBio: Tim Smith is a designer and frontend developer from Saint Paul, MN. He’s worked on the web for a decade, working with different companies and clients. Tim writes The Bold Report, a blog about design, development, technology, and most importantly, Star Wars. When away from his desk, he spends time with his amazing wife Kelly, eating brunch, watching movies, walking the mall, and other sappy-sounding couple stuff.

Results.Title: You can help milton from office space too
Results.Abstract:
I will be going over:
The Milton personality
What Milton goes through
How to help Milton
Q&A
Results.Author: Kevin Stanton
Results.AuthorBio:
Over the years I've struggled finding my social circle (living in front of the computer), and have enough courage to speak about how rough the life of the social outcast can be.

I heard the calling to give this speech from a coworker who is a younger version of myself.

Results.Title: Keeping Track Of It All: State Management in Modern Frontend Apps (with examples in Vue.js/Vuex)
Results.Abstract:
If you're like me you've worked on your share of frontend apps with data and state strewn every-which-way. Making sense of it all can be a nightmare!
What if you could put those days permanently behind you? What if all your UI components always had access to the state they needed? What if they were auto-magically updated and re-rendered when that state changed?  This is the promise of modern state management in frontend frameworks. Starting with the flux architecture, a proliferation of technologies and tools has emerged to help you keep track of it all.

This talk will explain the state management problem and show examples of how it is solved with Vue.js and Vuex. If those particulars are not your cup of tea, links will be provided to similar tools on all the modern frameworks.  Stop struggling with state. Learn how to keep track of it all!
Results.Author: David Dangerfield
Results.AuthorBio:
I've been a software developer for 16 years. I've done my time in the C++, Java and C# trenches. I discovered frontend development 4 years ago and I'm never going back! 

I work as a frontend developer at IBM in Rochester MN. I'm a huge fan of Vue.js and have used it professionally whenever I can. I also have professional Angular experience and have done lots of education on React. I especially enjoy frontend state management concepts and love to see clean minimal code in UI components wired up to the state they need.

https://www.linkedin.com/in/dangerfield

Results.Title: Getting started with Dart and Flutter
Results.Abstract: Flutter is a new mobile app SDK to help developers and designers build modern mobile apps for iOS and Android using the Dart programming language. While the project is still officially in Alpha, companies like Google are already using it in production. Come get introduced to the Dart language and how to make it Flutter building mobile apps.
Results.Author: Scott McAllister
Results.AuthorBio: Scott McAllister has over 10 years professional experience building applications in several industries. He joined Smartsheet several years ago, building integrations with the Smartsheet API using languages like Java, Node.js, and Python. Now he's helping others learn about a wide range of web technologies. When he's not coding, writing or speaking he enjoys long walks with his wife, skipping rocks with his kids, and is happy whenever Real Salt Lake can manage a win.

Results.Title: Advanced Fiddler Techniques
Results.Abstract: Fiddler is a great free web diagnostic tool that nearly everyone uses, but typically only for very basic things.  If all you need is to see the requests made between the browser and web server, the browser devtools can do that.  Fiddler has many more advanced features that most developers are unaware of.   It can be used to capture traffic from smartphones, tablets, and non-Windows platforms!  Discover the power of manipulating requests and responses with breakpoints, the auto responder, and a visual composer.  Review popular extensions for formatting JavaScript, syntax highlighting, and detecting image bloat.  Go beyond the basics and learn the full capabilities of the tool and how it can improve your web development and debugging techniques today!
Results.Author: Robert Boedigheimer
Results.AuthorBio: Robert Boedigheimer works for Schwans Shared Services, LLC providing business solutions with web technologies. Robert has been developing web sites for the past 23 years. He is a Microsoft ASP.NET MVP, a Progress Developer Expert (Fiddler), a Pluralsight author, and a 3rd degree black belt in Tae Kwon Do. Robert regularly speaks at national and international events.

Results.Title: Minecraft: Code, Visualized
Results.Abstract: Minecraft is a game full of blocks, squarely-shaped cows, and a lot of code. My job here is to show it to you, and give you a rundown on how it works.
Results.Author: Adam Nordquist
Results.AuthorBio: Hi! My name's Adam. I'm 15, and I spoke last year about Scratch, the programming language for kids. This year, I'll be talking about the code behind one of the biggest games ever: Minecraft. I hope I'll see you there!

Results.Title: Focusing on Focus
Results.Abstract:
When we think of CSS and Accessibility, what comes to mind? Is it adding alt attributes to image tags? How about color contrast? Is :focus given that much thought since browser's style these by default? Often, focus outlines are turned off in CSS to meet non-inclusive design standards, but this causes problems for keyboard users. How can we make the web a more inclusive place while maintaining design intent?.

As we build more and more things on the web, we must do our part in building awesome, accessible user experiences. Except native default browser styling of the :focus pseudo class is rather blah, don't you think? There has to be a better way to add some pizzazz to elements when users navigate without a mouse. In this talk, I will demo numerous ways to provide custom focus styles despite known limitations in the web platform. For users with disabilities, it's imperative that visual design finds a way to meet in the middle.
Results.Author: Chris DeMars
Results.AuthorBio: Chris DeMars is a UI developer first, UX architect always, working out of Detroit, Michigan. Chris is also an instructor, teacher assistant, and volunteer for the Ann Arbor chapter of Girl Develop It and co-organizer for the Ann Arbor Accessibiity Group. Chris loves coming up with solutions for enterprise applications, which include modular CSS architectures, performance, and advocating for web accessibility. When he is not working on making the web great and inclusive you can find him writing blog posts, watching horror movies, drinking the finest of beers, or in the woods of northern Michigan.

Results.Title: Hacking the Human Perception
Results.Abstract: Hacking you say? Yes, I do, but this type of hacking has nothing to do with hooking in Matrix style or surfing through The Gibson at Ellingson Mineral Company. Nope, this type of hacking involves how we as developers, create the illusion of fast load times for our Web applications. Performance is gaining much visibility in the industry and catering to the needs of the user, there are many things we can do to facilitate that need. This talk will focus on ways we can make things appear to be faster than they are and ways to avoid having to play Houdini entirely.
Results.Author: Chris DeMars
Results.AuthorBio: Chris DeMars is a UI developer first, UX architect always, working out of Detroit, Michigan. Chris is also an instructor, teacher assistant, and volunteer for the Ann Arbor chapter of Girl Develop It and co-organizer for the Ann Arbor Accessibiity Group. Chris loves coming up with solutions for enterprise applications, which include modular CSS architectures, performance, and advocating for web accessibility. When he is not working on making the web great and inclusive you can find him writing blog posts, watching horror movies, drinking the finest of beers, or in the woods of northern Michigan.

Results.Title: I Can't See: Low Vision A11y & Users
Results.Abstract:
When you think of low vision, what comes to mind? A user that is near sighted? How about far sighted? Maybe partially blind? These are all qualifying cases of poor vision, but low vision is more complicated than the prescription of glasses or contacts.

According to the World Health Organization, they categorize low vision based on specific levels of visual acuity and field of vision (W3.org, 2016). With that in mind, we as developers can look at different categories of low vision including color vision, visual acuity, contrast sensitivity, etc and make an effort to bake in things like zoom, non-conflicting colors, and re-wrapping of columns in to our code.

My talk will cover what vision accessibility is, different categories of low vision, what the needs of the users are, and what we as developers can do to achieve a great user experience for low vision users.
Results.Author: Chris DeMars
Results.AuthorBio: Chris DeMars is a UI developer first, UX architect always, working out of Detroit, Michigan. Chris is also an instructor, teacher assistant, and volunteer for the Ann Arbor chapter of Girl Develop It and co-organizer for the Ann Arbor Accessibiity Group. Chris loves coming up with solutions for enterprise applications, which include modular CSS architectures, performance, and advocating for web accessibility. When he is not working on making the web great and inclusive you can find him writing blog posts, watching horror movies, drinking the finest of beers, or in the woods of northern Michigan.

Results.Title: Ace the "Build Something" Interview:  Learn to live-code a Todo app in under 5 minutes (using Vue.js)
Results.Abstract: We all want to score a sweet job with a good company and great coworkers! But the best companies won't hire you until they've seen you code. They might ask you to build something while they watch. If you're not ready for this it could be a disaster! I'll teach you how to prepare for this type of interview. Along the way you'll learn the basics of Vue.js. Bring your laptop so you can code along. Don't be caught off guard! Be ready to show them what you've got!
Results.Author: David Dangerfield
Results.AuthorBio:
I'm a frontend developer at IBM in Rochester with 16 years of industry experience. I've done various types of development but in the last 4 years I've decided I'm frontend only. I am a huge fan of Vue.js! 
Feel free to contact me through LinkedIn: https://www.linkedin.com/in/dangerfield

Note to TCCC staff: I'm willing to give one of the talks I'm proposing. So pick your poison.  This one will cover the basics of Vue.js. The other one is advanced focusing on Vuex.  I just want to give a talk including Vue.js ... so feel free to contact me if you have a certain aspect of it that you think people want to hear about.

Results.Title: Real Pirates Seek the C!
Results.Abstract: We want you to experience the joys of the C! We'll help you get your C legs with simple tricks to make this venerable language work with the latest trends in programming. Simple project setup using Make and CMake. Functional programming. Test Driven Development & Automated Testing. Programming to interfaces. Design patterns. REST clients and servers. IoT. Cloud computing. We'll help you throw off the chains of Enterprise development, hoist the Jolly Roger, and deliver results faster, using fewer resources with this venerable, modern language.
Results.Author: Clay Dowling
Results.AuthorBio: I have been a software developer for more than twenty years.  I've made a lot of mistakes, and I'd like to help you learn from my mistakes.

Results.Title: Introduction to 3D Graphics
Results.Abstract: Ever wondered how video games generate those amazing scenes on your monitor?  What mystical mathematics goes into producing perspective correct buildings, extremely realistic lighting, and shadows?  In this talk, I'll introduce you to the basic concepts behind 3D graphics in a platform independent way and give you resources to learn more.
Results.Author: Josh Jones
Results.AuthorBio:
I'm a senior software developer in the Midwest primarily writing mobile applications and web services.

In my spare time (when I'm not hopelessly addicted to Elder Scrolls Online) I like to experiment with various languages, micro-controllers, and new gadgets (like VR headsets). I also do some 3D Art and 3D Printing on the side.

Results.Title: Sharpen Your Coding Skills with Project Euler
Results.Abstract: Project Euler is a collection of programming and math puzzles that can be solved in pretty much any language / platform. Join Dan as he explains the idea of Project Euler, touts the benefits of practicing your craft, and finds solutions to problems live on stage (with help from the whole audience, of course).
Results.Author: Dan Nordquist
Results.AuthorBio: Dan Nordquist is a software developer and technology leader in the Twin Cities. He is currently the Director of Technology at Bluespire Marketing, where he manages development, operations, and delivery. He's attended Twin Cities Code Camp many times over the past ten years, and has spoken at maybe four of them, in addition to some other speaking engagements around the country.

Results.Title: Azure ARM Templates - Why should I care?
Results.Abstract: Azure ARM templates are a real interesting way to provision resources in Microsoft Azure, but why would you want to use them when it's so easy to just go in and click some buttons in the portal? In this session we'll cover the basics of ARM templates with some basic demonstrations and explore the use cases in which you'd want to use them, and also the use cases when they won't add much value. We'll explore strategies for managing your own ARM template repositories and how to incorporate them into a continuous delivery pipeline.
Results.Author: Ken Sykora
Results.AuthorBio: I'm Ken Sykora, I am a technology enthusiast and a senior application developer at OST.  I'm an MCSD who specializes in cross-platform mobile, Web API, and cloud computing. I love everything about automation, scalable software delivery processes, and video games.

Results.Title: An Introduction to Artificial Neural Networks
Results.Abstract:
Do you want to predict customer behavior?  Evaluate the content of a photo or sound? Detect Fraud? Feed usage data back into your algorithms to improve them automatically? All of these things are being done today using Neural Networks for Machine Learning.  

This talk will cover the technologies used to create Neural Networks and give an introduction to the basics of why they work, the different types, and how they are being applied to today's business problems. The topics covered include:

• Artificial Neural Networks
• Convolutional Neural Networks
• Self Organizing Maps
• Recurrent Neural Networks
• Boltzmann Machines

You'll leave with an understanding of Neural Network terminology and basic concepts, and understand how these neural networks can be applied to real world problems.

TARGET AUDIENCE: Anyone interested in driving innovation
Results.Author: Cameron Vetter
Results.AuthorBio: Software Development is my passion. I have almost 20 years of experience using Microsoft tools to develop software. Currently I am the Principal Cloud Architect at Safenet Consulting, where I get to do what I love... Architect, Design, and Develop great software! I currently focus on Microservices, SOA, Azure, Neural Networks, and HoloLens.

Results.Title: Azure AI for Neural Networks
Results.Abstract:
Do you want to predict customer behavior?  Evaluate the content of a photo or sound? Detect Fraud? Feed usage data back into your algorithms to improve them automatically? All of these things are being done today using Neural Networks for Machine Learning.  

This talk will cover how to use the GPU power of Azure to train a Neural Network and how to turn that Neural Network into a REST service hosted in Azure. The topics covered include:

• Brief overview of Neural Networks
• Azure AI
• Azure Data Science Virtual Machines
• Python in Azure Web Apps\

You'll leave with an understanding of how to use Azure to train and host your neural networks.

TARGET AUDIENCE: Developers, Devops, Data Scientists, Architects
Results.Author: Cameron Vetter
Results.AuthorBio: Software Development is my passion. I have almost 20 years of experience using Microsoft tools to develop software. Currently I am the Principal Cloud Architect at Safenet Consulting, where I get to do what I love... Architect, Design, and Develop great software! I currently focus on Microservices, SOA, Azure, Neural Networks, and HoloLens.

Results.Title: Optimize Your Angular Runtime Performance
Results.Abstract: Ugh!  Performance problems!  Poor runtime performance can be frustrating for you and your customers.  While Angular (2+) is built to be efficient, it is not immune to these issues.  In this talk we will take a look at some Angular examples where runtime performance is an issue and go over a variety of techniques you can apply to your own project to speed up runtime performance.
Results.Author: David Stanich
Results.AuthorBio: David Stanich is an Advisory Software Engineer at IBM Watson Health, where he works on the front-end for oncology products.  When not working, he enjoys experimenting with technology and chasing around his two kids.

Results.Title: We Didn’t Stop to Ask If We Should: Understanding Build vs. Buy
Results.Abstract:
We were so preoccupied with whether we could, we didn’t stop to think if we should! Before debating React vs. Angular or .NET vs Node, we must ask ourselves, should we even build this? Whether you’re an entrepreneur launching a new project, an enterprise developer stuck integrating middleware, or a architect moving logic to the cloud, you’re making decisions that will have lasting consequences. Deciding which problems are worth your investment is at the root of success or failure.

Join us as we dig into real case studies from enterprises and startups. We’ll explore the options, costs, and risks inherent in deciding what to build, what to buy, and alternatives in between. We’ll consider the opportunity cost of building systems, the sustainability of open-source, and the risks of vendor lock-in. You’ll leave equipped to make better decisions in your daily development and solve the problems that matter.
Results.Author: Todd Gardner
Results.AuthorBio: Todd Gardner is a curmudgeon of a developer and cofounder of [TrackJS](https://trackjs.com/), where he helps thousands of developers find and fix bugs in their web apps. He believes in simple tools and systems over trends, and testing balanced against risk. He is also the producer and host of [PubConf developer afterparty](https://pubconf.io/). You can find him online at TODD.MN (yes, that’s his website). Ask him about craft beer, cool pubs, and maintainable software.

Results.Title: Getting Past "It Works Great on My Machine": Building A CI/CD Pipeline in Visual Studio Team Services
Results.Abstract:
I've been building applications for a long time, but I've never been "the build guy". Until recently, I've managed to avoid setuping automatic build and deployment pipelines. That being said, it's an important skill to have on your project team. The ability to get code off of your box and into production quickly is essential for developing agile software. The faster you can deploy, the more quickly you can adapt to change. Deploys should be like voting, done both early and often.

Over the past few months, I've gotten the chance to learn this important skill. This talk is for anyone who's new to building their own deployment pipelines. In this talk, you'll learn how to build and deploy an ASP.NET Core application using Visual Studio Team Services (VSTS). We'll begin with an application and work through the various choices in the process of getting from a repository of code to a deployed application in production. After this talk, you'll be able to build your own CI/CD Pipelines.
Results.Author: Dustin Ewers
Results.AuthorBio:
Dustin Ewers is a consultant at Centare, where he works to help businesses build better software. Dustin has been building software for over 10 years, specializing in Microsoft technologies. He is an active member of the technical community, speaking at user groups and conferences in and around Wisconsin.

While not building the software of the future, Dustin likes a mix of low tech and high tech hobbies, including reading, cooking, hiking, and fishing.

He writes about technology at https://www.dustinewers.com/.
Follow him on Twitter at @DustinJEwers

Results.Title: One Endpoint to Rule them All: Make your APIs Less Lazy with GraphQL
Results.Abstract:
APIs are a way of life for modern web developers. APIs based around access to individual resources, also known as RESTful APIs, have been the default for years. While REST has served us well, there are situations where REST isn't the best. Sometimes your data model isn't easily described as a few simple resources. Sometimes you don't want to bring back everything from the server. For those situations, we have a new way of accessing data, GraphQL.

GraphQL is a query language for your API. Created by Facebook in 2015 to speed up their mobile application, GraphQL has seen rapid adoption by companies including GitHub, Twitter, and Intuit. GraphQL simplifies requests by having the client define what data they want from the server. A single API endpoint can supply just what the client needs.

In this talk, you will learn about GraphQL and how it can make your APIs cleaner. You'll see how GraphQL compares to REST and when you would want to use each approach. You'll learn how to build a GraphQL API and a client application that uses it. After this talk, you'll be able use GraphQL to simplify your own APIs.
Results.Author: Dustin Ewers
Results.AuthorBio:
Dustin Ewers is a consultant at Centare, where he works to help businesses build better software. Dustin has been building software for over 10 years, specializing in Microsoft technologies. He is an active member of the technical community, speaking at user groups and conferences in and around Wisconsin.

While not building the software of the future, Dustin likes a mix of low tech and high tech hobbies, including reading, cooking, hiking, and fishing.

He writes about technology at https://www.dustinewers.com/.
Follow him on Twitter at @DustinJEwers

Results.Title: Answer ‘Hello World!’ with Twilio and Azure
Results.Abstract: This is a walkthrough of creating an over-the-phone timecard system using Twilio and Azure in C#. Write applications that make and receive calls, send and receives SMS messages and much more very quickly with Twilio. All hosted without any in-house hardware.
Results.Author: Keith Voels
Results.AuthorBio: I've been a .NET Developer for 15 years and currently I am an Application Architect at Aon. We develop and maintain a global platform of 40+ internal line of business applications that serve all areas of the business group. We have the full spectrum of application technologies from web to native to mobile.  I am in personally charged with the shared services framework with a focus on bringing in new technologies and establishing new frameworks and patterns. My passions include the business layer, Async / Await and dependency injection.

Results.Title: Async / Await in C#: Pain in the Async
Results.Abstract: Async/await is great and easy!! Until it’s not. This will be a walk thru of the areas where Async / Await can be difficult and how to deal with them. Topics include: Task, avoid Async void, deadlocks and ContinueWith and exception handling. Each topic includes code examples. This is for developers who are already comfortable using Async/Await.
Results.Author: Keith Voels
Results.AuthorBio: I've been a .NET Developer for 15 years and currently I am an Application Architect at Aon. We develop and maintain a global platform of 40+ internal line of business applications that serve all areas of the business group. We have the full spectrum of application technologies from web to native to mobile.  I am in personally charged with the shared services framework with a focus on bringing in new technologies and establishing new frameworks and patterns. My passions include the business layer, Async / Await and dependency injection.

Results.Title: Functional Business Rules in C#
Results.Abstract: Modern frameworks like LINQ, Autofac and Reactive Extensions help make our lives easier and are great examples of functional programming. We’ll discuss why and how you can use functional programming to make your own business rule code cleaner, more readable and maintainable. We’ll walk thru an open-source project that implements functional business rules for CSLA.
Results.Author: Keith Voels
Results.AuthorBio: I've been a .NET Developer for 15 years and currently I am an Application Architect at Aon. We develop and maintain a global platform of 40+ internal line of business applications that serve all areas of the business group. We have the full spectrum of application technologies from web to native to mobile.  I am in personally charged with the shared services framework with a focus on bringing in new technologies and establishing new frameworks and patterns. My passions include the business layer, Async / Await and dependency injection.

Results.Title: High performant in-memory datasets with Netflix H0110W
Results.Abstract: Are you encountering problems which require dissemination of small-mid size datasets? Do you need to distribute this data across multiple regions on different clouds or on premises? Probably you are sending this data to a NoSQL data store and querying it in runtime or distributing JSON/XML files across all your servers to accomplish this. Netflix Hollow is a java library and toolset for disseminating in-memory datasets from a single producer to many consumers for high performance read-only access. In this talk I will show how Hollow can help you to distribute datasets on different environments using blob storages for KB, MB or few GB of data, optimizing the performance of your applications and achieving extreme stability and reliability by showcasing different aspects of Hollow and potential use cases for it in your projects
Results.Author: Roberto Perez Alcolea
Results.AuthorBio: Roberto is an experienced software engineer and Groovy enthusiast who loves coding and enjoys contributing back to the community. He has several years of experience using Groovy and Grails and currently enjoying technologies such as Ratpack, RxJava, Kafka Streams and Netflix Hollow.

Results.Title: Xamarin Data Syncing
Results.Abstract:
How can your users continue to use your mobile application while offline? A look into how and why to make a mobile app work where a data connection is not available and how to keep that data synchronized between the device, cloud and other devices. 

Offline sync allows users to interact with a mobile application, viewing, adding, or modifying data, even where there isn't a network connection. Changes are stored in a local database, and once the device is online, the changes can be synced with the web service.
Results.Author: Andrew Cook
Results.AuthorBio: Andrew Cook is a software developer, speaker, and Paramedic with experience in the Microsoft Stack specializing in cloud application development. You can find more from Andrew on his blog: https://codingwithcookie.com/ . You can also find him on twitter: @codingwcookie (https://twitter.com/codingwcookie).

Results.Title: Guided by Types
Results.Abstract:
One of the things I love about strongly typed languages is that you can tell what something should do just by looking at the type signature.  In this talk we'll look at how we can use types to guide our software development.  We'll look at how using Generic Types, Algebraic Data Types, and Depend Types we lean on the type checker do most of the development for us.

You'll walk away from this talk with a greater idea of how to leverage types in your day-to-day coding.
Results.Author: Mike Harris
Results.AuthorBio: Mike Harris is a software crafter and lifelong learner, who is constantly searching for the best tools for the job. Mike enjoys learning new program languages and ways of solving problems. He uses this knowledge in his day-to-day work as a Software Developer at Baird.

Results.Title: Continuous Feedback
Results.Abstract:
One of the great things about crafting software is that you can get quick feedback.  Want to know how something works in a language or framework?  Fire up a REPL.  Want to know what will happen when that method you just wrote is given a certain type of input?  Write a unit test.  Want to make sure that your code will work with the code your teammates are writing?  Set up a continuous integration server.  Want to make sure that you are building what your users want?  Deliver small chunks as often as you can.  Want to know how your users are actually using?  Set up logging.

In this session we'll look at how to get continuous feedback on what we are doing.

You'll walk away with some tips and tricks on how to integrate continuous feedback into the work you are all ready doing.
Results.Author: Mike Harris
Results.AuthorBio: Mike Harris is a software crafter and lifelong learner, who is constantly searching for the best tools for the job. Mike enjoys learning new program languages and ways of solving problems. He uses this knowledge in his day-to-day work as a Software Developer at Baird.

Results.Title: Building High Performance React Applications
Results.Abstract: React is built with performance in mind. But when is React slow? In this talk we’ll discuss common bottlenecks in React and when you might be making your program work harder than it should.
Results.Author: Joe Karlsson
Results.AuthorBio:
Joe is a JavaScript Engineer and Tech Lead at Best Buy and has been teaching full stack JavaScript for the past 2+ years. He likes to build software with friends and explore new connections in art and software.

Twitter - @JoeKarlsson1
Github - @JoeKarlsson
LinkedIn - /in/joekarlsson
Website - joekarlsson.com

Results.Title: How HTTP/2 Can Speed Up Your Web Application Today
Results.Abstract: HTTP/2 is the new version of the web's and the Internet's most important and widely used protocol. Joe explains what it is, why it matters, how widespread the use already is and what might be up next in HTTP land.
Results.Author: Joe Karlsson
Results.AuthorBio: Joe is a JavaScript Engineer at Best Buy and has been teaching full stack JavaScript for the past 2+ years. I like to build software with people and explore new connections in art and software.

Results.Title: Hack-Free Layouts with CSS Grid
Results.Abstract: The only things certain in life are death, taxes, and hacking your way through a CSS layout -- until now. Come for a deep dive on CSS Grid, a framework-free, library-free, layout system that is orchestrated for designing today's modern web applications. After an hour, you'll come away rejuvenated that you don't have to hack layouts any longer - and enjoy designing responsive layouts using only the CSS specification.
Results.Author: Dave Brock
Results.AuthorBio: Dave Brock is a software engineer at CUNA Mutual Group in Madison, Wisconsin, where he is a "full-stack developer" in the Microsoft stack - working on C#, SQL Server, as well as front-end work with JS and TypeScript. He enjoys speaking and sharing his knowledge - especially in Florida in wintertime - and blogs at his site (daveabrock.com). When not at his day job, he enjoys various side coding projects and being ordered around by his two small children and his not-so-small dog.

Results.Title: Getting Comfortable with Authentication in .NET Core
Results.Abstract: .NET Core offers various authentication options, and as such it's easy to get confused. Do I stick with Windows authentication? Do I implement a storage provider? What about external authentication through Facebook or Google? What about two-factor authentication? Azure Active Directory? Come join me for an hour to discuss all the options at your disposal and how you can cut through the noise and pick the best method for your application.
Results.Author: Dave Brock
Results.AuthorBio: Dave Brock is a software engineer at CUNA Mutual Group in Madison, Wisconsin, where he is a "full-stack developer" in the Microsoft stack - working on C#, SQL Server, as well as front-end work with JS and TypeScript. He enjoys speaking and sharing his knowledge - especially in Florida in wintertime - and blogs at his site (daveabrock.com). When not at his day job, he enjoys various side coding projects and being ordered around by his two small children and his not-so-small dog.

Results.Title: Don't Panic!  A Hitchhiker's Guide to Emergencies in Software Delivery
Results.Abstract:
We've all been there. It's the end of your release cycle and a doozy of a defect is discovered. A production issue has suddenly flooded your inbox with alerts. A critical customer has relayed their deep dissatisfaction and they want their problem addressed now… or else.

Afterwards, we often focus our energy on preventing emergencies like these in the future.  However, what if you and your organization put a fraction of those efforts towards preparing for the next time the alarm goes off?  Simple changes in how you and your organization react will pay big dividends.  Your company can get back to business as usual sooner.  Your customers can get quick satisfaction.  Most importantly, you and your colleagues can retain your sanity.

This talk will examine high pressure situations commonly faced in software delivery to identify simple improvements that can be made.  Whether you are an engineer or CIO, you have the power to make enhancements to behaviors and processes that will result in happier customers and less stressed employees.
Results.Author: Martin Hertz
Results.AuthorBio: Martin Hertz is a leader in the engineering group at Jamf, where he supports multiple delivery teams. He has about 17 or so years of professional experience, including roles as developer, architect, process expounder, and manager.  He has always approached people, product, and process challenges from the perspective of "how can we do this better?"  He has been fortunate to learn over the years from smart coworkers, mentors and his mistakes.

Results.Title: Why loop in JavaScript when you can map, reduce or filter?
Results.Abstract: Traditionally, when developers see large arrays of data their "go to" tool for parsing and searching has been the for loop. But JavaScript provides a more declarative approach that can help you find what you're looking for in fewer lines of code that is cleaner, easier to read, and maintain. Come see how the map(), reduce(), and filter() functions can help you!
Results.Author: Scott McAllister
Results.AuthorBio: Scott McAllister has been building web applications in several industries for over a decade. He joined Smartsheet several years ago, building integrations with the Smartsheet API using languages like Java, Node.js, and Python. Now he's helping others learn about a wide range of web technologies. When he's not coding, writing or speaking he enjoys long walks with his wife, skipping rocks with his kids, and is happy whenever Real Salt Lake can manage a win.

Results.Title: From Junior to Senior: Why we Teach
Results.Abstract:
Hiring good software developers is hard. Mentoring entry-level software developers is also challenging. Why would you consider hiring a junior-level engineer? How do you balance the decision to hire and mentor someone entry-level with the need to create high quality software efficiently?

In this talk, we’ll discuss the importance of hiring entry-level developers: from the cultural to the technical impacts. From a senior developer’s perspective, we’ll chat about why you should embrace the junior-dev hire and some practical tips for managing focus (and patience) with teaching.
Results.Author: Amy Gebhardt
Results.AuthorBio: Amy is an extroverted software developer with a traditional Computer Science background and a passion for technology and people. She is happiest when writing client-side code on her Mac in collaboration with a crazy smart, dedicated team. Currently, she is the Lead UI Engineer at SportsEngine and spends her time working with designers, engineers, product managers, and architects to build and maintain a reusable Component Library.  As a 30 out of 30 on the Myers Briggs extroversion scale, she loves to get involved with local MeetUps, attend conferences, and lead the Minneapolis Girl Develop It Chapter.

Results.Title: Develop Add-ons for Google Apps AND Stay Sane
Results.Abstract: With Google Apps Script, Google has provided a way for developers to add functional to Google Suite apps. While using Google's in-browser editor to write sample Google Add-ons can be handy for extremely basic scripts, it gets clunky fast when developers want to do something like version control their code or have more than one person working on a script. With the help of a couple open source projects, developers can now build Add-ons on locally, on their own machines, with the tools they're most comfortable with.
Results.Author: Scott McAllister
Results.AuthorBio: Scott McAllister has been building web applications in several industries for over a decade. He joined Smartsheet several years ago, building integrations with the Smartsheet API using languages like Java, Node.js, and Python. Now he's helping others learn about a wide range of web technologies. When he's not coding, writing or speaking he enjoys long walks with his wife, skipping rocks with his kids, and is happy whenever Real Salt Lake can manage a win.

Results.Title: A Practical Approach to the Component Library Challenge
Results.Abstract:
Component libraries, design systems, style guides, and pattern libraries: more buzzwords and best practices that you can’t stop hearing about. 

Perhaps your dev team could really benefit from a reusable component library or your designers need some encouragement to keep consistent within their mockups. Maybe your team already has a handful of patterns scattered throughout various CSS projects and you’re hoping to find a better way to maintain it all.  Sounds like a win, right? The spirit of the idea is great, but like most best practices, a practical implementation is time consuming and challenging.

In this talk, we’ll dive into a practical approach for creating a component library. We’ll chat about the complete project from design processes to technical infrastructure decisions to quality standards and how a component will actually show up on your user’s device. Come get a practical guide to answering the right questions, prioritizing the appropriate requirements, and get on your way starting your own library!
Results.Author: Amy Gebhardt
Results.AuthorBio: Amy is an extroverted software developer with a traditional Computer Science background and a passion for technology and people. She is happiest when writing client-side code on her Mac in collaboration with a crazy smart, dedicated team. Currently, she is the Lead UI Engineer at SportsEngine and spends her time working with designers, engineers, product managers, and architects to build and maintain a reusable Component Library.  As a 30 out of 30 on the Myers Briggs extroversion scale, she loves to get involved with local MeetUps, attend conferences, and lead the Minneapolis Girl Develop It Chapter.

Results.Title: Getting started with Machine Learning
Results.Abstract: One of the most exciting new developments in computer science, yet shrouded in mystery - what even *is* machine learning, and what can I do with it? Find out answers to these questions and more as we go over concepts (and applications!) of teaching AI's to think for themselves.
Results.Author: Joshua Longanecker
Results.AuthorBio:
Good at some things, bad at others. But getting better.

Self-taught Sr Software Engineer. Javascript saved my life.

Results.Title: Overcoming Behavioral Challenges on Development Teams
Results.Abstract:
In a perfect world, individuals could self select onto high performing teams where everyone is productive and gets along famously.   In the real world, teams are formed by circumstance, schedule, and availability.    As a result,  behavioral dynamics on a team can impair its ability to be productive and efficient.   

This session surfaces the most common sources of individual behavioral differences and challenges.   The objective is not to offer tips to change people, but rather, to learn to overcome those differences.    Concrete tips and techniques will be provided that participants can take back to apply on their own teams.

Learning Outcomes:

	• Behavior Measurement
		○ Overview and comparison of popular behavior and personality measurement tools including DISC, MBTI, Strength Finders and Spiral Dynamics
		○ Risks to avoid when  "measuring" and labeling people
		○ Measuring, calibrating, and monitoring individual and team behavior
		○ Tips and techniques  to incorporate and use these measures effectively on project teams
		○ NOTE: Participants will be provide a free DISC assessment worksheet to complete on their own and use with their teams.
	• Conflict
		○ Recognize and understand common sources of conflict
		○ Discerning good conflict from bad conflict
		○ How to measure team concordance/discordance
		○ Tips and techniques for transforming conflict into effective decisions
	• Change Aversion
		○ Understand why change is hard for some, easy for others
		○ Recognizing good change from destructive change
		○ Change management by role 
			§ Product Owner
			§ Scrum Master 
			§ Development Team Member
			§ Stakeholder
	• The Agile Introvert
		○ Agile practices that intrude on  an introvert's natural tendencies
		○ Understand behavioral and motivational differences between introvers and extroverts
		○ Examples of team working agreements to accommodate needs of introverts and extroverts
	• Additional brain stuff that's useful to know
		○ How to avoid building the wrong thing due to false memories
		○ Making better commitments by overcoming Dunning Kruger, Illusory Superiority, and replacement ignorance phenomena
		○ Understand why  procrastination occurs, and how to overcome it
		○ Additional behavioral anti-patterns
Results.Author: Ken Howard
Results.AuthorBio: Ken Howard is co-founder and executive at Improving, with offices in the Twin Cities and across North America.  He has provided consulting, training and mentoring to companies in 12 countries around the world, helping with adoption of software development best practices.  He is also on the computer science faculty at Southern Methodist University.   Ken specializes in individual and team performance, which was the topic of his Addison-Wesley book titled Individuals and Interactions: an Agile Guide

Results.Title: An Intro to Go for System Engineering
Results.Abstract: With all the benefits and versatility of the Go language, we will examine and explore the benefits and drawbacks to using the Go over Python for automating systems engineering tasks. We intend to leave you with a basic understanding of the fundamentals of the language so that you could walk away and start programming in Go immediately.
Results.Author: Richard Isaacson and Mary Scaramuzza
Results.AuthorBio:
Richard Isaacson has spent his career focusing on operations and development. In his day job, he supports development teams in their migration from legacy systems to AWS services. Outside of work and family, he is a student in the MSSE program at the U of MN. For fun, he enjoys looking in to how new technologies can help us better run our systems.

Mary’s work has focused on solving search and analytics problems. She enjoys digging into the fundamentals of new languages and understand the designs behind new software. She is also a student in the MSSE program at the U of MN.

Results.Title: GitHub Pages: A Platform For Cheapskates
Results.Abstract: In this session Mike will give the pros and cons of using GitHub Pages to host your site for free. We'll go into the basics of setting up a new repo and built-in functions to add a little dynamicity to your static site. He will show you how to set up a local development environment on Windows, how to add an acceptance environment to your flow, and we'll look at a few third party services to complement your available toolset.
Results.Author: Mike Cole
Results.AuthorBio: Mike Cole is a developer currently focusing on .NET working remotely from Cedar Falls, IA. He's been around the proverbial block in the IT profession and has a wide array of experience in many fields. He is incredibly lazy and is always looking for easier and more streamlined ways to solve everyday problems. His passions in life include his family, sarcastic memes, the outdoors, and always having the last word.

Results.Title: The Trials And Tribulations Of Being A Fully Remote Developer
Results.Abstract: Imagine working from home full-time. Your job choices are not limited geographically. You have a nice quiet workspace in your comfortable home with limited distractions. Lunch break in your easy chair. What's a dress code? You don't have to go outside in the morning during a frigid Iowa winter. Sounds perfect. Now imagine this actually happening to you and nothing goes to plan. How do you stay motivated? How do you deal with communication breakdowns? The feelings of isolation? Of feeling like a second rate employee of the company? In this presentation, Mike will review the tips and techniques he has learned over the past several years while being a full-time remote developer. This session is geared both towards developers and managers of remote development teams.
Results.Author: Mike Cole
Results.AuthorBio: Mike Cole is a developer currently focusing on .NET working remotely from Cedar Falls, IA. He's been around the proverbial block in the IT profession and has a wide array of experience in many fields. He is incredibly lazy and is always looking for easier and more streamlined ways to solve everyday problems. His passions in life include his family, sarcastic memes, the outdoors, and always having the last word.

Results.Title: Using GraphQL to Get Exactly What You Need from an API
Results.Abstract:
When accessing a typical RESTful API, you get whatever data the API you're calling deems appropriate. You will probably receive a lot of data you don't need and if you need different types of data you may have to call multiple endpoints. Released publicly by FaceBook in 2015, GraphQL helps to lessen the pain of interacting with APIs by allowing clients to query exactly the data they need--nothing more, nothing less. 

In this session, we will learn how to use GraphQL  by accessing some well-known APIs (like Reddit and GitHub). We will also briefly discuss how you can build your own GraphQL-based API in .NET.
Results.Author: Ed Jones
Results.AuthorBio: I am a Software Engineering consultant for Avanade in the Twin Cities and have been in the development biz for about 20 years. Currently, I specialize in Azure Cloud, Integration, API,  and .NET development but I'm always looking to learn something new. I've served my clients in many roles, including as a developer, architect, technical lead, mentor, and trainer.

Results.Title: WebAssembly: A Whole New Web Dev Experience
Results.Abstract:
Web development is about to undergo a major change! For many years now people have tried to create new web development languages and experiences on top of JavaScript. This was done by transpiling or compiling code into JavaScript.

Now there's an exciting new option: WebAssembly. All modern browsers now have the ability to run assembly language AND JavaScript, which means a lot of existing languages can now run in the browser. Languages such as C, Go, and even C#.

If you've held off on web development because of JavaScript, or been a reluctant JavaScript user, WebAssembly offers you alternatives. The browser is no longer a mono-culture, and the future is very exciting!
Results.Author: Rockford Lhotka
Results.AuthorBio:
Rockford Lhotka is CTO at Magenic, the leading modern application development firm that addresses your toughest, most complex software development challenges and delivers results.

Rockford is the creator of CSLA .NET, one of the most widely used development frameworks for Microsoft .NET.

He is the author of numerous books and speaks at major technical events around the world. Rocky is also a Microsoft Regional Director and MVP.

Rockford has worked on many projects in various roles, including software architecture, design and development, network administration and project management. Over his career he has designed and helped to create systems for bio-medical manufacturing, agriculture, point of sale, credit card fraud tracking, general retail, construction and healthcare.

Results.Title: Tools of the trade: Error Logging, Web Request Tracing, and Background Jobs for your .Net applications
Results.Abstract:
In this talk, we'll cover basic functionality and usage of three free tools for working with .Net applications.

The first tool we'll use is Hangfire for background jobs. This is an easy-to-add, lightweight tool for processing background work and allowing for us to integrate processes that would have needed a background service in the past. Hangfire is free and has a paid upgrade version available for additional functionality. It's also easy to add to your projects via nuget.

The second tool we'll look at is Elmah for error logging. This tool is available for free as a nuget package, and can be easily wired up to log your errors, as well as other critical application information at the time of the error.

The final tool we'll look at is Stackify Prefix, which is a great tool for looking into your web requests, and can specifically help you recognize instances where you might be overworking your web and database resources.

All of the tools are good for any .Net application, however in this talk we'll be using a default ASP.Net MVC classic application for the purposes of our demonstration. All tools also work with .Net core applications.
Results.Author: Brian Gorman
Results.AuthorBio: I am an experienced .Net developer, previously certified as an MCSD .Net in C#.net [expired]. I have a masters of science degree in computer information systems, and a bachelor of science degree in computer science. I also have many years of experience instructing college courses online in SQL databases, C#/VB .Net programming, Java programming, and Microsoft Office. I have created many online technical training courses that can be found on various platforms like O'Reilly/InfiniteSkills, Udemy, and others. I also run MajorGuidanceSolutions, a training and consulting company ,while working fulltime as a .Net developer.

Results.Title: Build a Full Stack .Net Core MultiTenancy Web Application with Angular using ASP.Net Boilerplate
Results.Abstract:
In this session, we'll go from the ground up to a fully functional .Net Core Web application using Angular on the front-end. This is accomplished with a free framework: ASP.Net Boilerplate.

We'll start by getting a project up and running, which does have a few tricks. Once we're up and running, we'll be able to move very quickly through some of the key points of the layered architecture.

We'll build a model and create the code-first migration to set the database using Entity Framework Core. We'll then build an application service that leverages dependency injection to work against our data. We'll Swagger our service so that the front-end can leverage the automatically generated service proxies.

Our UI layer will leverage Angular and will be fully built in typescript with less and html. With a few notes about some wiring most of the "hard" work of angular is handled for us, and we can concentrate on coding our systems.

Authentication and permissions are a breeze, as are managing roles and user permissions, making setup for multi-tenancy with various user roles fairly painless. This is accomplished through an admin user that can manage users and roles, and also by locking down various methods in our service with code.

The guys at Volosoft have thought of mostly everything - even setting up a built-in multi-lingual architecture. Furthermore, if you need a more powerful solution that has built in masquerading, a full version of the product is available for purchase at ASP.Net Zero.
Results.Author: Brian Gorman
Results.AuthorBio: I am an experienced .Net developer, previously certified as an MCSD .Net in C#.net [expired]. I have a masters of science degree in computer information systems, and a bachelor of science degree in computer science. I also have many years of experience instructing college courses online in SQL databases, C#/VB .Net programming, Java programming, and Microsoft Office. I have created many online technical training courses that can be found on various platforms like O'Reilly/InfiniteSkills, Udemy, and others. I also run MajorGuidanceSolutions, a training and consulting company ,while working fulltime as a .Net developer.

Results.Title: Forgot Password? Yes I Did!
Results.Abstract: Every month we hear about a new data breach, and billions of user passwords are being shared as we speak. How can we stop this? There is a simple solution: let’s stop using passwords! From email links to biometrics, more and more technologies are available to help developers handle different types of credentials. During this presentation, the attendees will learn about some of the alternatives and how to implement them in the context of an OAuth flow.
Results.Author: Joel Lord
Results.AuthorBio:
Joel Lord is passionate about web and technology in general. He likes to learn new things, but most of all he likes to share his discoveries. He does so by travelling to various conferences all around the globe.

He graduated with a college degree in computer programming back in the last millennium. Apart for a little break to get his BSc in computational astrophysics, he has always been in the industry. As a technical evangelist with Auth0, he meets with developers to help them make the web a safer place.

During his free time, he is usually found stargazing in a campsite somewhere or brewing a fresh batch of beer in his garage.

Results.Title: Hacking JWTs
Results.Abstract: So you’ve finally implemented your own authorization server. And it uses JWT because everyone else does. But is it secure? JWTs are the new great thing that everyone is talking about, but you need to use them correctly. During this talk, we will see how we can use various attacks to hack into OAuth systems that use JWTs as a token mechanism. From token validation to brute forcing HS256, by seeing the attackers’ point of view the attendees will learn how to better defend themselves and make more secure servers.
Results.Author: Joel Lord
Results.AuthorBio:
Joel Lord is passionate about web and technology in general. He likes to learn new things, but most of all he likes to share his discoveries. He does so by travelling to various conferences all around the globe.

He graduated with a college degree in computer programming back in the last millennium. Apart for a little break to get his BSc in computational astrophysics, he has always been in the industry. As a technical evangelist with Auth0, he meets with developers to help them make the web a safer place.

During his free time, he is usually found stargazing in a campsite somewhere or brewing a fresh batch of beer in his garage.

Results.Title: WTH is a JWT
Results.Abstract: Chances are, sooner or later your shiny new single page application will need authentication. Add some security and resource access control to that list as well. But how can we integrate all of this into a single page application that is entirely public? How can we ensure that the users cannot hack their way into the restricted parts of the app by using the console? In this talk, the attendees will learn about JSON Web Tokens (JWT) and see how they can be used to properly secure single page applications.
Results.Author: Joel Lord
Results.AuthorBio:
Joel Lord is passionate about web and technology in general. He likes to learn new things, but most of all he likes to share his discoveries. He does so by travelling to various conferences all around the globe.

He graduated with a college degree in computer programming back in the last millennium. Apart for a little break to get his BSc in computational astrophysics, he has always been in the industry. As a technical evangelist with Auth0, he meets with developers to help them make the web a safer place.

During his free time, he is usually found stargazing in a campsite somewhere or brewing a fresh batch of beer in his garage.

Results.Title: Blazor: C# running in the browser via WebAssembly
Results.Abstract: Microsoft officially joined the SPA framework race with the announcement of Blazor, an experimental SPA framework for running C# client-side in the browser via WebAssembly. In this session, we'll discuss what WebAssembly is, why this isn't another Silverlight, and then we'll dive into Blazor to understand how it works. You won't want to miss these demos.
Results.Author: Scott Sauber
Results.AuthorBio: I'm primarily a web developer using ASP.NET Core, JavaScript, and embarrassing myself trying to write CSS.

Results.Title: Building Large, Yet Maintainable, ASP.NET Applications
